Description: Temptation of St Christopher (formerly Temptation of St Antony); St Christopher kneeling in a turf hut at right, twenty-two scenes of temptation before him, including monstrous creatures and an elaborate sea-creature or boat in the middleground; numbered 1-22 throughout composition to indicate the scenes of temptation. 1561 Etching and engraving
Producer name: Print made by: Johannes van Doetecum I
Print made by: Lucas van Doetecum
Curator's comments: The subject has traditionally been described as the temptation of St Antony but it is in fact the temptation of St Christopher (in the form of a giant figure). During conservation work on this engraving, an anonymous Italian drawing of an academic youth was discovered; see also 1866,0407.42.+. The drawing was apparently used as a backing sheet by an earlier collector before it was acquired by the museum in 1866. Literature: M. Ilsink, in J. van Grieken - G. Luijten - J. van der Stock, "Hieronymus Cock: The Renaissance in Print", exh.cat. Royal Library of Belgium in Brussels and Fondation Custodia in Paris, New Haven and London, 2013, cat.no.64.
Bibliographic references: Hollstein / Dutch and Flemish etchings, engravings and woodcuts c.1450-1700 (10) (after Hieronymus Bosch)
New Hollstein (Dutch & Flemish) / The New Hollstein: Dutch and Flemish etchings, engravings and woodcuts 1450-1700 (216) (The Van Doetecum family)
Lafond 1914 / Hieronymus Bosch, son art, son influence, ses disciples (13)
Riggs 1977 / Hieronymus Cock, Printmaker and Publisher (9)
Exhibition history: 2007/8 Oct-Feb, BM P&D, Whales in Print
Associated names: Representation of: St Antony of Egypt (formerly identified as)
